body: WHEN you hoist a leg over a barstool these days, you're as likely to find Tom Edison as a Tom Collins. Light bulbs have been popping up behind the bar, with more cocktails developed in the last 10 years than probably any decade since Prohibition. Some of them have emerged as modern classics, standing out not only as culinary creations, but also as
title: A Decade of Invention, and Reinvention

body: AT this 11th hour of the wild Christmas goose chase -- and this is true whether the economy is bustling or bristling -- most normal people are afflicted with that weird state of anxiety, anticipation, dread and panic that the Germans call shopenfreude. O.K., so they don't -- but I do. Unfortunately, the usual cure for shopenfreude is running
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER | MXYPLYZYK; A One-Stop Christmas for Dawdlers

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: Ann Kansfield, who runs a weekly food pantry at the Greenpoint Reformed Church in Brooklyn, cannot bring herself to tell you this, so I will: She doesn't want your cans. As uncharitable as it sounds, she doesn't want your holiday food drives. Don't be offended. She knows you are well meaning; just misguided, perhaps misinformed. Cans of food are
title: BIG CITY; To Feed the Hungry, Spread the Word: Cash Is Preferred Over Cans

body: AN empty pizza box was propped against a black fiberglass urn in the hallway outside Three's Company, a gallery that is also the living room of Alex Gartenfeld and Piper Marshall, roommates in a tiny tenement walkup in Chinatown. ''That's what can happen to the art after a show,'' said Mr. Gartenfeld, indicating the urn, which he explained had been
title: Is It Art or Their Shoes?

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: What is the sound of one eye rolling? Call Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger, and tell him you want to engage in that wonderful holiday tradition of volunteering on a soup line in the third week of November. ''Thanksgiving is to hunger groups what Halloween is to a costume company,'' he said. ''Sometimes
title: CITY CRITIC; Warm Intentions, Meet Cold Reality

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM Opening on Wednesday and running through Jan. 18, the eighth annual Holiday Train Show, with cars representing the Long Island Rail Road and Metro North, as well as the New York City subway system. Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturday and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; closed on
title: Spare Times

body: Maggie Nesciur was 7 when she started exploring city streets on foot. Terrified of a man who was a fixture in her subway station, she would get off at a nearby stop and walk. After high school, she traveled widely, but returned to Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 2003, after being diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma, a rare cancer. Even during a year of
title: One in 8 Million : New York Characters in Sound and Images

body: For almost two years, city officials have extolled a proposal for a five-borough network of water taxis, an ambitious plan that the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said would make New York ''a shining example of urban sustainability for cities all over the world.'' The plan moved quickly. A ferry linking the Rockaways, in Queens, to
title: East River Commuter Ferry Service Could Be Halted, Again

body: IF you are of the view that nurture trumps nature, you might not have predicted a career as a professional comic for Kumail Nanjiani. He grew up in Pakistan -- ''Not necessarily a very funny place,'' he says -- and had never seen a moment of stand-up comedy until he came to Iowa for college and watched a Jerry SeinfeldHBO special. In his
title: COMEDY; It's Not a Bad Time To Be Funny in the City

body: Over the past seven years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has presided over a historic re-envisioning of New York City, one that loosened the reins on development across the boroughs and pushed more than 100 rezoning measures through a City Council that stamped them all into law. His administration poured $16 billion into financing to foster commercial
title: A Stalled Vision: Big Development As City's Future

body: JASON MILLER, a 38-year-old furniture designer best known for creating a popular ceramic chandelier in the shape of antlers, no longer lives in a loft. ''In a factory space or an industrial space, there's a certain level of finish that's not there,'' he said. ''You make do with chewing gum and tape.'' Last December, Mr. Miller, who had spent more
title: ON LOCATION; An Ode to '70s-Style Living

body: The mostly empty pews at the Lutheran Church of the Messiah spoke of a dying congregation. But as the 17 worshipers returned to their seats after communion on a recent Sunday, they faced a more encouraging symbol: guitars, keyboards and drums poking up from the choir loft, hinting at the church's double life. The instruments belong to two rock
title: GREENPOINT JOURNAL; A Place to Worship, and to Jam, Shop and Feast

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is closing in on a milestone: building or preserving 165,000 city-financed apartments and houses for low-, moderate- and middle-income families, the goal of a $7.5 billion housing plan he announced in 2002 and expanded in 2005. It has already financed the creation or preservation of 94,000 units, including 72,000 for
title: As the City Gains Low-Income Housing, the Market Takes It Away

body: In a landscape I could barely recognize, I stood balanced atop a 140-foot-high silver egg. The wind picked up as I traversed a narrow walkway to the top of another egg, apparently of the same bizarre species, and then another and another. Below me -- very far below me -- lay huge pools teeming with microbes. I saw bridges in the distance, rivers
title: CITY CRITIC; The Doors Are Open, So Snoop Away

body: A BROOKLYN DERBY For Urban Anglers It's out there somewhere. Urban anglers of all skill levels are being challenged to grab their rods and reel in Brooklyn's biggest fish. The Brooklyn Fishing Derby, promoted as ''the first-ever New York City common man's fishing competition,'' began on Thursday night and will run until the end of the month. The
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: This article was reported by Simon Akam, Alison Leigh Cowan, Michael Wilson and Karen Zraick, and written by Mr. Wilson. For years, he was a fixture in Lower Manhattan, as regular as the sunrise. Every morning, Najibullah Zazi would be there on Stone Street with his pastries and his coffee, his vending cart anchored to the sidewalk. For many on
title: From Smiling Coffee Vendor to Terror Suspect

body: Opening this Week MERCAT NEGRE Here's a geography lesson. Mercat, the parent restaurant in Manhattan, focuses on the city of Barcelona, but with the owner Jaime Reixach's new place, opening on Sept. 24, he not only moves out to Brooklyn, but also moves out of Barcelona, giving the Catalan cuisine the rusticity of the Girona area to the northeast.
title: Off the Menu

body: Every day, people walk into Grand Central Terminal and look up at the vaulted ceiling over the main concourse, with its star constellations and zodiac signs. It helped make the station ''a triumphant portal to New York,'' in the words of one of its architects, Whitney Warren. People who walked into the Empire State Building have done their looking
title: Overhead, A Lobby Is Restored To Past Glory

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: WHEN Jean-Marie Grenier was growing up in the Norman village of Rugles, he lived on a street called Rue du Cimetière. On funeral days, women wearing long black veils padded by behind a horse-drawn hearse, a sight that terrified him as a little boy. ''Les dames en noir,'' recalled Mr. Grenier, 56, a sculptor who immigrated to New York in the late
title: HABITATS; The Two-Story Conversation Starter

body: TAXI DRIVERS Share Their World Cabbies, though their work facilitates many a New Yorker's daily life, are often overlooked, known to their passengers only as a snapshot on a license floating in a corner of the cab's plexiglass divider. So it was a refreshing change when five New York City cabdrivers faced an audience from a small stage in a
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: AUDIO SLIDE SHOW Jane and Jean-Marie Grenier live in a former funeral home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and tell cabbies that their building ''looks like a church but it's not.'' nytimes.com/realestate
title: Online

body: Jane and Jean-Marie Grenier tell cabbies looks like a church but its not, when they go to their house in a former funeral home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
title: Spirits Replaced With Joie de Vivre

body: Bob Visintainer sat in Washington Square Park on Wednesday cradling an acoustic guitar. Two days earlier, the city announced a plan to ban smoking at parks and beaches. Mr. Visintainer, strumming a D chord, said people smoking in parks was not something that bothered him. But trash overflowing from garbage cans? That's worth cracking down on. ''It
title: So the City Likes to Ban Things. How About These?

body: For all the inroads made by hipsters in Greenpoint, Brooklyn's northernmost neighborhood, it has retained much of its Old World Polish character and working-class grit (probably because its subway is the much-loathed G train). It's a great place to fill up on tasty, shockingly cheap Polish food -- kielbasa, pirogi and bigos, the cabbage and meat
title: LOCAL STOP | GREENPOINT; A Taste of Poland in Arty Brooklyn

body: It's said that every vote counts. This is particularly true of a number of City Council races in New York City on Sept. 15, when a few hundred votes could determine who will occupy a front-row seat in city government. Here are our endorsements for several of the most competitive districts where winning the Democratic primary usually means capturing
title: EDITORIAL; For New York City Council

body: The noise of skateboard wheels thrumming on wooden ramps echoed near the Brooklyn waterfront in Greenpoint on Saturday night, where a semisecret skating spot called the Autumn Bowl is located inside an old brick warehouse. Photographs of the New York City skateboarding pioneer Andy Kessler decorated the walls inside the warehouse, and bouquets of
title: Generations of Skaters Gather to Pay Tribute To a Legend of the City

author: E-mail: streetscapes@nytimes.com
body: IS the 1955 Donnell Library on West 53rd Street a rare piece of midcentury Modernism? Or an empty suit of expressionless masonry? As the vacant building heads toward demolition in two years, a cadre of preservationists still hope to convince the Landmarks Preservation Commission that the limestone facade is not a nothing, but a something. The
title: STREETSCAPES | THE DONNELL LIBRARY; A Spartan Beauty or a Plain Old Beast?

body: 'IT CAME FROM BROOKLYN' Sorry, Baltimore and Portland, Ore., Brooklyn's reign of cultural supremacy is not ending anytime soon. At least that's the message of the Guggenheim Museum's new monthly performance series, It Came From Brooklyn. Part of the museum's 50th-anniversary celebration, the series, which begins on Friday, includes music, readings
title: Spare Times

body: TORI MELLOTT, who was the decorating editor at the now-shuttered Domino magazine, lives in a West Village one-bedroom apartment that is the anti-Ikea. She is among a small group of people who don't, when they are craving a certain kind of furniture, simply go out and buy it; she has it made and is a self-described ''custom junkie.'' The queen-size
title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; Can't Find the Right Furniture? Have It Made

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made a plan to create housing for half a million low- and moderate-income New Yorkers one of his signature initiatives, driving the rezoning of swaths of New York City to create what city planners call the largest municipal affordable housing plan in the nation. But in one neighborhood, the rush to build affordable
title: Old Feuds Resurface in a Brooklyn Rezoning Fight

body: VALISA AND JAMES TATE were among the first residents to move into One Brooklyn Bridge Park, a condominium project in Brooklyn Heights, in the summer of 2008. A year later, the hallways still feel barren. Only 77 of the building's 438 apartments have closed. Twenty-six are in contract. In order to keep money coming in during a difficult time for
title: Renters to the Rescue

body: THE FIERY FURNACES, the indie-rock duo made up of the siblings Matt and Eleanor Friedberger, are releasing ''I'm Going Away'' (Thrill Jockey) on Tuesday. A conscious nod to the recession, the album is more pared down in its arrangement than their six previous studio albums, but even the most musically sparse songs pulse with a rich narrative. Matt,
title: PLAYLIST | THE FIERY FURNACES; Off the Beaten Path, Surrounded by Rebels

His quartet, assembled here for brunch duty, features Seamus Blake on saxophones, Chris Lightcap on
title: THE LISTINGS

body: ALEX NICOLA, who will be 5 in August, enjoys being naked as frequently as possible at home. ''In the morning he gets up and takes his pajamas off, and rather than get dressed right away, he walks around naked,'' said Dawn Nicola, Alex's mother, a stay-at-home parent in Castle Rock, Colo. After school, he likes to take off his pants, recline on his
title: When Do They Need a Fig Leaf?

body: EAT 124 Meserole Avenue (Leonard Street) Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-8083, eatgreenpoint.com. When Eat Records opened in Greenpoint in 2003, it was four-fifths used-records store and one-fifth coffee shop, with a few tables crammed beside floor-to-ceiling shelves of vinyl. In recent months, it's become a fully fledged cafe, shedding the
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED

body: BROOKLYN'S PLACE In the Beer World For a while, the beer flowed from Brooklyn as if from a broken spigot. With 45 breweries at the turn of the 20th century -- including 11 on a 12-block stretch in Williamsburg -- Brooklyn produced a significant share of the nation's beer. But if the names Rheingold and Schaefer do not provoke a feeling of parched
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: Who needs Renoir's barges on the Seine? Jose Gaytan is enraptured by scows on the Gowanus. Almost every day for the past six years, Mr. Gaytan, with his two dogs, has crisscrossed the streets and bridges near the Gowanus, Brooklyn's famous canal, photographing moments of serenity, color and beauty amid the decaying postindustrial landscape.
title: By the Gowanus, A Painterly Lens On the Ruins Amid a Rebirth

body: LIKE other property-hungry renters in New York City, Janet Hicks recently decided to take advantage of the weak real estate market and buy her first home. But instead of getting an apartment in the city, she chose to become a first-time buyer in a second-home market. While keeping the one-bedroom rental she shares with her boyfriend in Park Slope,
title: The New Country Squires

body: LAST summer a sad but hopeful question made its way through Brooklyn: Where will the Pool Parties go? It was the third year of concerts in McCarren Park Pool, the disused 1930s public swimming hole on the Williamsburg-Greenpoint border, and they had begun to feel like an institution. Each Sunday afternoon the shows drew thousands of the young and
title: Keep the Music, Add the Views

body: FOR two uneasy years, Mark Sussman and Jessica Suarez lived in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Shortly after their arrival, their apartment was broken into. They added security alarms. It was broken into again. After losing four laptops, they decided they couldn't risk losing more. ''I was sure it was just a matter of time'' before yet another burglary, Miss
title: THE HUNT; More Than a 'Flop Pad'

body: The event was a fancy corporate dinner in a public garden on the Lower East Side, a celebration of locally grown food. The second course listed on the menu was ''grilled Queens farm pork loin,'' which sounded as if the dish had been created by someone from Queens. Then a man pulled up a chair and was introduced as Michael Grady Robertson from the
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Trend and Tradition Meet at a Queens Farm

title: THE LISTINGS

body: THIS summer, Tony Tomelden hopes to be making bloody marys at the Pug in Washington, D.C., with tomatoes and chilies grown above the bar, thanks to the city's incentives for green roofs. Mr. Tomelden, the Pug's principal owner, says he's planting a garden to take advantage of tax subsidies the city offers in his neighborhood if he covers his roof
title: Urban Farming, A Bit Closer to the Sun

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. THE AVETT BROTHERS (Friday and Saturday) Country music has a rich tradition of brother duos: the Statler Brothers, the Louvin Brothers, the Gatlin Brothers and on and on. The Avett Brothers, from North Carolina, aren't a country band, exactly -- their twangy, harmonized pop songs borrow from
title: THE LISTINGS

body: TIME marches on. People move, and move again. Now, on the fifth anniversary of The Hunt, it's time to catch up with some of those who so graciously shared their house-hunting tales. Creature of Habit Five summers ago, Nicole Davis, who lived in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, took a half-share in a house in Montauk on Long Island, and she was relieved to
title: THE HUNT; So Where Are They Now?

body: The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about Greenpoint, Brooklyn, overstated the effect of a 1950 explosion in polluting Newtown Creek, an estuary along the neighborhood's boundary. The explosion contributed some of the polluting petroleum, not ''much'' of it. In addition, the process of contamination was described incorrectly. The oil seeped into
title: CORRECTIONS

body: As usual, Thu Tran was trying to do two things at once. In the living room of her apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, its floor littered with glittery scraps of paper, she was supervising two friends who were decorating balloons and beach balls to be tossed to the crowd at a D.J. show the following night. Meanwhile in the kitchen she was adding
title: A Foodie With a Taste for the Surreal

body: THERE was a time, not long ago in the grand scheme of things, when the only practical way to get in and out of Greenpoint was by boat. In those days, as late as the mid-19th century, the area was separated from much of the rest of Brooklyn by marshland and flanked on the north and west by Newtown Creek and the East River. Overland crossings were
title: LIVING IN | GREENPOINT, BROOKLYN; Polish Is Still Spoken, but Industry Is History

body: FOR two decades, Steven Leeds and Rachel Hott lived in Montclair, N.J., an hourlong train-and-subway commute to their office near Union Square in Manhattan. But with their two children almost grown, Mr. Leeds, in particular, wanted a quick trip to work. A short walk was his ideal. The idea of a move back to the city was fine with his wife. After 25
title: THE HUNT; The Six-Minute Test

A mayoral appearance is less government in action than stage management; liturgy without Scripture but with scripts. And as Mr.
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; A Heretic To the Gospel Of Bloomberg

title: THE LISTINGS

body: ON Sunday, hundreds lined up outside the Highline Ballroom in Chelsea for the Tofu Takedown, paying $10 each to eat bean curd cooked by amateurs, and vote on their favorite dishes. The crowds were still streaming in when the host, Matt Timms, 35, got on the microphone. ''These people are incredible!'' Mr. Timms shouted. ''They made all this food
title: In New York, the Taste of Victory

body: There is little that is cozy about ''HomeBase IV,'' a site-specific installation built around a dozen artists' notions of home. It is installed in a vacant medical clinic on the Lower East Side, unused for three years but still carrying the unmistakable whiff of an institution you don't want to be in. ''When we arrived, it had nothing in it,'' said
title: At a Clinic, Artists Reflecting On Home

body: ANDREW BAISLEY described himself as a ''cheerleader for Brooklyn'' -- at least until a month ago, when the proud Bushwickian decided to take a peek at the Manhattan rental market. Now he has a one-bedroom in Chelsea with outdoor space and a 10-minute commute, all for an ''unbelievable'' $2,100 a month. ''When you go to Manhattan, there's an air of
title: Manhattan Calling

body: Alabama CITY STAGES Birmingham, June 19-21. This eclectic festival, which invades downtown for three days every summer, is comprised of a seemingly random selection of gospel, hip-hop, jazz, folk and rock 'n' roll acts, including Jane's Addiction, Young Jeezy, Indigo Girls, Charlie Wilson, the Neville Brothers, En Vogue, the Doobie Brothers, Guster
title: Summer Stages: Pop/Jazz

body: AT the northernmost tip of Brooklyn, in the area east of McGuinness Boulevard, there is an industrial wilderness, a home for rumbling trucks and silent brick warehouses adorned with wooden signs and chipped paint. But on the corner of Paidge Avenue and Provost Street, just a short distance from Newtown Creek, a boulder sits like a giant trail
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Ironic Nature Walk

body: TOMORROW, the seventh annual show of designs created in Brooklyn -- Bklyn Designs -- will open in Dumbo, drawing renewed attention to this neighborhood of former factories and warehouses, and its vibrant design scene. Over the last six years, the juried show, which features contemporary furnishings, lighting and accessories designed, and in most
title: Made in Brooklyn

BELL ORCHESTRE (Thursday) This instrumental band from Montreal, which happens to share a few members with the Arcade Fire, creates songs so rich and dizzying -- mesmerizing, careening melodies that mimic early psychedelia as much as traditional chamber music -- that it's easy to forget that
title: The Listings

body: 1. GREGORY KRUM likes to mix it up. As director of retail for the Shop at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, he stocks its grass-green vitrines (adapted from a 1962 Fritz Haller design) with objects he singles out for their craftsmanship, quirkiness, contextual relevance or just plain beauty. ''I try to keep the shop focused yet full of the
title: THE GET; In-Store Mini Cooper

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. LILY ALLEN (Monday) This spunky British songstress has built a career around the notion of the sweetly delivered kiss-off; in 2007 her ''Smile'' (''At first, when I see you cry, it makes me smile, yeah it makes me smile''), skewered a former suitor's attempts at reconciliation. Still, Ms.
title: The Listings

body: THE industrial slivers of northern Brooklyn and western Queens that sit in the shadow of the Kosciuszko Bridge are, to most New Yorkers, forsaken territory. But on these hinterlands near the Kosciuszko, the aging bridge that connects Greenpoint, Brooklyn, to Maspeth, Queens, along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway over Newtown Creek, is a thriving
title: GREENPOINT/MASPETH; Uneasily Contemplating the Arrival of a Spiffy Newcomer

body: Wells Tower's book of short stories, ''Everything Ravaged, Everything Burned,'' has attracted a great number of vivid descriptions from admiring critics in the few weeks since it came out, and ''strange'' is perhaps the most commonly employed. Also: ''lurid''; ''crammed with more pathos than a 400-page potboiler''; ''bittersweet,'' ''beautiful''
title: Witness to Luckless Lives on the Periphery

body: FRED HUA'S banh mi pho does not look like a cultural revolution. But in its juicy, messy way, it is. Served at Nha Toi in Brooklyn, where he is the chef and owner, banh mi pho is stuffed with the ingredients for pho, the sacred soup of Vietnam: beef scented with star anise and cinnamon, fresh basil and crunchy bean sprouts. ''I could never get away
title: Building on Layers of Tradition

body: An article on March 22 about the News Corporation's acquisition of The Brooklyn Paper misstated the reason that Aaron Short, a reporter, left The Greenpoint Courier, another newspaper owned by the corporation. Mr. Short was let go because the newspaper shut down; he was not fired.
title: Correction

body: JAZZ Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. title: The Listings

body: EARLIER this year, a restaurateur in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, named Cody Utzman posted a comment on his blog in which he described his newest neighborhood venture, a store specializing in organic foods, as a small grocery, a general store and a market. By the time an article about the project appeared in The Brooklyn Paper about two months later, he
title: GREENPOINT; The Classic Bodega Takes a Star Turn

body: McCarren Park Pool, right, located on the border between Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn, is set to become a swimming spot again, and the summer rock concerts that put it on the musical map will move to the Williamsburg waterfront. title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Outdoor Concerts Find a New Home

title: The Listings

body: The woman at the desk of A & L Collision, an auto repair shop in Brooklyn, eyed Officer Neil R. Stevens suspiciously. ''You're not from here,''' she said. ''Yes I am,'' Officer Stevens replied. ''You dress differently,'' she insisted. She had a point. Officer Stevens's uniform is olive green, not blue, and he wears a Stetson hat that gives him a
title: Don't Be Fooled by the Hats: These Officers Are For Real

body: Imagine you're scouting locations for a television series, a biblical allegory that unfolds in a contemporary monarchy. The script calls for a clean, new capital ''unspoiled by time or litter,'' modern with a touch of Renaissance Revival, ''a city to make you believe in magic.'' Would you ever choose New York City? The production team from NBC
title: New York, a City Unspoiled. Wait, New York?

body: THIS is not an obituary. The Brooklyn Paper lives. Since 1978, it has been a ''loud, offbeat and somewhat irreverent'' voice in the borough, in the words of its founder and publisher, Ed Weintrob. The paper did, however, undergo something of a transformation this month when it was purchased by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. Just what this will
title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; A Scrappy Local Paper Ponders Its New Parent

body: ERIK PARKER says he has never taken a class in color theory. ''I just like things to be charged and relentless,'' he said as he showed a visitor around his studio in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. That is evident in his eye-popping new work, on view through April 28 at Paul Kasmin Gallery in Chelsea, where Mr. Parker is having his first New York paintings
title: ART; No Longer Racing at the Speed of Art

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. THE ALLMAN BROTHERS BAND (Friday, Saturday, Monday, Tuesday and Thursday) This archetypal Southern rock band is still on the road. Gregg Allman, the band's keyboardist and main singer, is more than ever its center, since its co-founder, Dickey Betts, is estranged from the band. His
title: The Listings

body: ROBERT GUSKIND was serious to the point of obsession about his blog, Gowanus Lounge, founded in 2006. So Sam Coker, an information technology specialist from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, who over the years helped Mr. Guskind maintain the site, knew something was wrong. title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; For a Cherished Blog, A Death, and Doubts

body: IN 1986, when Anders Goldfarb moved to Greenpoint, Brooklyn, he was a young photographer with a master of fine arts degree from the State University of New York at New Paltz. body: A former New York City police officer was arrested on Monday and charged with fatally shooting his 28-year-old former companion and wounding another woman in a Brooklyn apartment on Sunday, the authorities said. The ex-officer, Jerry Bowens, 43, was alone in a car when heavily armed officers intercepted him at 3 a.m. about a block from the 120th
title: Former New York Police Officer Charged in Fatal Shooting

body: A former New York City police officer who resigned last year after being arrested on corruption charges is suspected of fatally shooting his 28-year-old ex-girlfriend and wounding another woman in Brooklyn on Sunday, the police said. The police said the shooting happened shortly after 4:30 p.m. inside Apartment 1B of a condominium building at 84
title: Ex-Officer Suspected Of Shooting 2 Women

body: Even the film and television industry, one of the few fields generating profits in the throes of this recession, says it needs government help to stay in New York. title: A Plea to Keep Cameras Rolling in New York

body: IF the choreographer Megan Byrne were wealthy, she said, her days would consist of ''class in the morning, rehearsal in the afternoon and steak for dinner.'' But Ms. Byrne, 29, like many in the contemporary dance world, is not wealthy. Far from it. Instead of paying for class and a steak, she said, the reality for many of her uninsured,
title: DANCE; New Classes Fill New Needs in Movement

body: There were heaps of clothes inside the church hall, including wool sweaters and what looked like a pair of lederhosen that somebody might have once worn in the Alps. There were children's toys and a box of designer sunglasses. A table held books, including ''Fortress America,'' by William Greider, about the American military after the cold war; and
title: An East Village Market Where Everything Is Free Faces an Uncertain Future

body: It was around 3 in the afternoon when Alex Kapranos's hangover began to wear off. body: WHEN a former community organizer named Barack Obama began his bid for the presidency, it cast a spotlight on an uncelebrated profession. In New York, the history of community organizing is long, and Luis Garden Acosta has been around for much of it. Born in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to a Puerto Rican mother and a Dominican father, Mr. Acosta, 63,
title: THE VOICE; Since the '60s, a Place on the Ramparts

body: BEYOND Mexico and the Caribbean, another ''New World'' of cuisine still awaits many New Yorkers. These three restaurants offer some surprising flavors from South America. title: $25 AND UNDER; The South America Less Traveled

body: Some alumni donate stadiums. Others give benches spiffed up with gold plaques. title: Two Used Truck Engines? You Shouldn't Have!

body: ONE thing that the owners of the Austin, Nichols & Company warehouse at 184 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, were firm about throughout the long battle over the building's fate three years ago was that it was not historically valuable. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, which declared the 1915 structure a landmark, disagreed, but
title: WILLIAMSBURG; At an Old Warehouse, A Reversal of Fortune

title: Spare Times

body: BEFORE asking the waiter at Five Leaves about a drink on the cocktail list, the Whiskey in a Jar ($9), I had to ask about his tattoos. They were that striking. title: $25 AND UNDER; A Neighborhood Feel Despite Its Pedigree

body: ON a recent Saturday morning, my friend Judith and I shopped for breakfast at the farmers' market in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. We bought eggs, butter, cheese, fresh bread and plenty of apples: the makings of a princely meal. I chattered enthusiastically about the apple French toast and scrambled eggs with cheese we could whip up back at Judith's house.
title: A GOOD APPETITE; Fish and Eggs: It's What's for Breakfast

body: New York City has created more than 100 miles of bicycle lanes in recent years to encourage and accommodate the number of people who, compelled by a desire to preserve the environment or preserve their bank accounts, have taken to getting around on two wheels. But the effort to turn the city into a place that embraces bicyclists has clashed with a
title: Bike Lanes Touch Off Row in Williamsburg
